$PLTR extended its Airbus partnership for 10 years in a $1B deal with Skywise remaining a core operating system for airline operations at scale.

While $100M per year is immaterial for a ~$340B company, I view this $1B as foundational for future AI monetization since every Skywise customer becomes a natural distribution channel for Palantirâ€™s AIP.

$TSLA drivers in Oregon can now get up to a 50% insurance discount when using FSD (Supervised) through $LMND new autonomous insurance program.

The more miles driven on FSD, the lower the premium with broader state expansion planned.

$NBIS is acquiring Tavily for $275M to add real-time search infrastructure for AI agents across use cases like coding and trading.

This moves Nebius further up the stack from infrastructure toward owning the agent tooling layer.
$OSCR flying after that massive 2026 guidance

Michael Saylor says $MSTR has no plans to sell Bitcoin and expects to keep buying every quarter viewing volatility as an opportunity.

His long-term thesis is that $BTC can still double or triple S&P returns over a 4â€“8 year horizon despite near-term pressure.

Buying $AMZN at ~$208 (~$2.2T market cap) implies youâ€™re getting:

â€¢ $269B e-commerce growing ~10% (arguably worth ~$300B)
â€¢ $129B AWS growing ~24% (easily a ~$1.8T business)
â€¢ $69B ads growing ~23% (a ~$500B business))

On a sum-of-the-parts basis, that points to Amazon being closer to a ~$2.6T valuation or ~$250 per share.

Databricks completed a $7 billion funding round, including $5 billion in equity and $2 billion in debt, valuing the firm at $134 billion.

Databricks added that its revenue run rate surpassed $5.4 billion, up 65% YoY, with AI products reaching a $1.4 billion run rate. 

$SNOW $MSFT $AMZN $NVDA

TSMCâ€™s $TSM 2nm capacity is reportedly almost fully booked, with Apple $AAPL said to take more than half of capacity this year, while GPUs and ASICs from AMD $AMD, Google $GOOG and Amazon $AMZN are expected to ramp in 2027 on the node.
Tune in to Making Money with @cvpayne at 2pm EST where I share my thoughts on the recent software stock selloff.

ðŸ“º SOFTWARE SECTOR: TACTICAL OVERSOLD BOUNCE, NOT A TREND REVERSAL

Software $IGV is seeing a short-term oversold bounce, not a trend reversal.

The sector remains broken after losing key moving averages, so upside is likely limited near short-term resistance like the 8-day. 

Some notable software stocks are participating in the bounce alongside the sector:

â€“ $MSFT remains a broken bounce, not a confirmed trend change. There may be room toward near-term resistance, but it still carries single-stock risk and should be treated tactically, not as a longer-term setup.

â€“ $ORCL is showing some relative strength versus most software names after reclaiming the 8-day moving average. However, it remains a broken name structurally, with major resistance overhead, making this just a trade, not a long-term bullish signal.

â€“ $NOW is lagging and approaching a key resistance zone where broken bounces often fail. Any upside should be viewed as short-term mean reversion, with heightened risk as price moves into known trouble areas.

This is a tactical, countertrend tradeâ€”take profits quickly, manage risk tightly, and donâ€™t confuse a bounce driven by sentiment extremes with a sustainable bullish shift.

ðŸ“º BULLS TOOK CONTROL: HEREâ€™S THE LEVEL THAT MATTERS

Active bulls regained control after $SPY held the $687 level and followed through on Fridayâ€™s strength. 

Small caps $IWM and mid caps $MDY continue to lead, while $QQQ works back into key moving averages. 

As long as $SPY holds above $680, sideways action would be constructive and could set up a push to new highs ($SPX to 7000). 

It looks like this move was a real commitment, not just a one-day bounce.
$SPX futures +10 after Fridayâ€™s action put active bulls back in control and yesterdayâ€™s dip was bought off 6902â€”7002 remains the ATH pivot into Wednesdayâ€™s jobs report.

ðŸ“º HOW TO FRAME TRADES IN MEGA-CAP TECH RIGHT NOW

Recent strength in mega-cap tech was used as a source of funds rather than sustained upside. So, what's next?

â€“ $GOOGL had strong earnings but was sold into. The key level to watch now is ~$319â€”holding it keeps the trade viable, losing it opens downside and likely signals weak follow-through across all mega caps.

â€“ $AMZN is a potential gap-fill trade toward ~$214, but failure to fill that gap would invalidate valuation arguments (Amazon is at its lowest valuation ever) and suggest staying away.

â€“ $MSFT is a broken bounce with resistance near $408â€“$420 after a rejected gap down.

â€“ $NVDA remains range-bound; ~$182 is the critical supportâ€”holding it could stabilize price, losing it would be disappointing and difficult to trade.

â€“ $TSLA offered a trade off the 200-day moving average into the 8-day, and now must prove it can hold higher and reclaim resistance.

â€“ $AAPL has been the best recent performer for me. It is now above key moving averages and may work toward $300, though it looks somewhat extended. I am keeping an eye on $AAPL.

So, frame trades tightly around clear levels. If leaders canâ€™t turn green and hold support, upside in mega-cap tech is still limited.
